body: This still consistently fails build on AppVeyor VS2017; @dougmsft @motus have you looked into why?
Arr! Let's see if we have more luck with the next build. (I've just pushed changes re: your code review)
Thank you - its been rebased.

The [error](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/1708-master/job/pyyaqdyih5itvioc#L10972) is in `VS2013`.

I'm not sure if this is a real error or transient.

```
"C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\TestRunner.proj" (default target) (1) ->
"C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.csproj" (Test target) (9) ->
(Test target) -> 
  C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\xunit.targets(52,5): error MSB3073: The command "..\packages\xunit.runner.console.2.1.0\tools\xunit.console.exe ..\bin\x64\Debug\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.dll -notrait Environment=Yarn -html ..\bin\x64\Debug\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\\xunit_report.html" exited with code 1. [C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.csproj]
```
Note that while this fixes the incompatibilities, the analyzer will still report an issue. More details on the [JIRA issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1586).
The test error is one of the transit.
LGTM and I will commit once we see the output of the build.
@motus there is one transit test error in 2015 in AppVeyor. All others are passed.
2013 and 2015 builds are good. 2017 failed on 2 IMRU tests which are transient so I think this is ready to commit.
Cool! @dougmsft could you please merge?
Okay
I was able to replace the body of the registration loop with `this.register(cls) ` as you suggested. This is where my C++ templates and java generics differ. Thanks for the suggestion.

I wish they did! A clean build on this pull request is an accident, two builds of the same bits on my clone of the repository both fail, one with protoc version missing and the other with `TestFailMapperEvaluatorsOnDispose` failure.

But building in Release definitely doesn't introduce new constant failures.
2017 and 2015 builds are good and 2013 build has one transient failure, so this pull request is ready unless you have more comments.
@motus Do you want to merge this PR? I don't expect I'll need to do any changes, it's very straightforward
Any possibility to enable both debug and release builds?

@jwang98052 It is possible if we spawn three more jobs (debug x VS 2013, VS 2015 and VS 2017 + release x VS 2013, VS 2015 and VS 2017), though I don't remember the syntax off the top of my head. But this means that each build will take 3 hours (each build job takes about 30 minutes, and they are executed sequentially, not in parallel). We already see queue blocked sometimes when several pull requests are updated at nearly the same time or one pull request is updated with a minor fix, with 3 hours per build it will only get worse - we'll be able to squeeze in just a couple of builds per day. I really don't want to do that.

Do we really need both debug and release builds? I thought release includes everything done in debug
Agree. LGTM. I will merge it,
LGTM.
LGTM, will merge.
@nhne How about adding tests on `RemoteManager` using `HttpMessagingTransportFactory`?
Added one Test on `RemoteManager` with `HttpMessagingTransportFactory`.
LGTM, will merge.

Unless I misunderstand something about the CLR, I think that a runtime switch won't work because we can't compile REEF for the `2.0 Standard` if we include these libraries.

However, we currently already use the `DOTNET_BUILD` compile-time flag to signal variations necessary for a Core build. See for example the [IConnectionRetryHandler](https://github.com/apache/reef/blob/687e02ab3573f140f6d37d6c4a50344b2c0b54cb/lang/cs/Org.Apache.REEF.Wake/Remote/IConnectionRetryHandler.cs).

Perhaps instead of flagging `WINDOWS` here, I should rewrite this to use the `DOTNET_BUILD` flag.

What would your preference be?

I don't think this will really solve the problem. Our evaluator in this test doesn't do any calculations, so if it doesn't complete in 1 minute, it most probably won't complete in 90 seconds as well. I suspect that tests which fail due to timeout are actually indication of some messages lost, some race condition in evaluator shutdown or something like that.

This looks good to me.

(See my comment on [PR-1343](https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/1343) I accidentally started the conversation over there.)
LGTM, will merge

> Perhaps instead of flagging WINDOWS here, I should rewrite this to use the DOTNET_BUILD flag.

Yes, we should use the target flag instead of an OS flag.
Okay, this has instructions up to date with `master` with `REEF-1841` checked in.

This readme includes hardcoded version of REEF. Instead of saying "replace this version with correct version when you're editing the files" (this is rather tedious), we can add this file to our script which updates all mentions of REEF version in our files with the new version. Thus as part of the release the version will be updated automatically and this phrasing will no longer be necessary.

https://github.com/apache/reef/blob/master/dev/change_version.py
LGTM, will merge

I'm concerned about this approach to "fixing" issues. I can't rule out timing issues with the same confidence as @tcNickolas, though.

If we believe that our transitive failures are indeed due to timeouts that happen because the test environment is deterministically much slower than other environments, we should solve it with a test run specific slowdown factor, and not by hard coding new timeouts for all test runs.

On the java side, we solved it via `org.apache.reef.tests.TestEnvironment.getTestTimeout()` which can be implemented in a per-environment way.

@rogancarr Have you checked that replacement code in Python is giving correct results for both entries of version? The new version provided for the script is in format `0.16.0`, and at a glance it seems that both `Version=0.15.0.0` and `Org.Apache.REEF.Evaluator.0.15.0` will be replaced with `0.16.0`, losing the last zero in `<Reference>` tag. (Sorry I don't have the environment set up to run the script and check this myself)

I agree with you @tcNickolas and @markusweimer , if there is some thing wrong that prevent driver to shut down, extend wait time won't help. 

Initially I see this test has a DriverWaitTimeoutMilliseconds that is set to 1 minute. So I thought we should wait longer than it in reading driver log file (default is 60 retry that is one minute). Looking at it carefully again, looks like it should not impact the driver shut down time. 

Yesterday I got test failure in EvaluatorRequestingDriverSpecifyingRuntimeName locally, the test was not able to read log file but the driver eventually shut down. The common thing between those two tests is that there is no context submitted, the evaluator is disposed in IAllocatedEvaluator. The IAllocatedEvaluator.Dispose() eventually calls AllocatedEvaluatorImpl.Close() that calls EvaluatorManager.close(). Usually, with context and task scenarios,  we call ActiveContext.Close() that reaches to code path EvaluatorContext.Close(). 

@markusweimer do you know if there is any difference between close evalautor through context and close evaluator directly without submitting context?

HashTable cannot be sorted. In fact, as long as we generate context ids and ensure they are unique and sorted by it, it should be safe.  I have made the change, removed the dependency on the partition data descriptor id for sorting.

> @markusweimer do you know if there is any difference between close evalautor through context and close evaluator directly without submitting context?

Interesting. An `AllocatedEvaluator` isn't actually running anything, not even `Evaluator.exe`. Hence, this shutdown should be much, much faster. We have a test for this in Java in `org.apache.reef.tests.close_eval.CloseEvaluatorTest` which on my machine runs very fast. Hence, the reason for the slowdown is more likely to be either in the Bridge or the .NET code. However, nothing obvious comes to mind. All that code does is to call `.close()` on the java side. Maybe the bridge assumes a different call order?

Maybe a next step is to write a test just for this code path?

I actually don't think it is caused by slow. Just wondering if we call different Close(), would that really triggers the driver to shut down? The code in EvaluatorManager.close() and EvaluatorContext.Close() are different.
Miracle of miracles no transient test failures.

Achuth R
Looks like a transient test failure so I will review.

### 1. Bug fixed.
Filled out missing points on the control flow.

### 2. Unit Test - all passed.
Test environment was a cluster that consists of 3 nodes, one for master and two for slaves. One slave is labeled as "mylabel" and another one wasn't.

I configured yarn for node labeling testing(including enable node labeling, set capacity of each partition) manually, and carried out three cases.

1. Set label for the job, and request a resource without label.
2. No label for the job, but driver requests a resource with a specific label.
3. No label for the job, and one request is for labeled resource, and another is not.

All of these tests came with the expected results. #1, #2 retrieved a container from the labeled node and #3 retrieved a contaier from the labeled node and another from the node without label.

### 3. Excluded the test from the commit

I excuded the [test](https://github.com/craig1583/reef/tree/TestNodeLabel)
 from this commit because it is not reproducible. YARN configuration must be set before running the test and should be restored. However to do this, you have to restart running yarn cluster. I think it would be problematic if it affects other running jobs.

You can attach node label on job or individual resource request.
For a job, bind named parameter `NodeLabelExpression` on driverConfiguration. It will set the label on every resource requests for the job.
For an individual evaluator request, you can set label like this way.
```java
EvaluatorRequest.newBuilder()
          .setNumber(1)
          .setMemory(500)
          .setNumberOfCores(1)
          .setNodeLabelExpression("mylabel")
```

I don't like adding the feature without a test for it. A feature not covered with tests is an invitation to accidentally break it and not find out until a year later, like it happened with driver restart feature.

Is there any way at all to include this test (do you mean `ResourceRequestEventImplTest`?)? Make it run in sequence with others, not in parallel, and do changes to Yarn configuration before and after? Change Yarn configuration of all tests before executing them? At the very least  keep it in the code and add instructions to running it manually as part of release process.

Now that I think of it, we should probably also document running driver restart example and include it in release... @jwang98052 Thoughts?

@tcNickolas [This](https://github.com/craig1583/reef/tree/TestNodeLabel/lang/java/reef-tests/src/test/java/org/apache/reef/tests/nodelabel) is the test for node labeling.

Of course I can provide node labeling example code separately with yarn cluster setup instruction. (on JIRA?) But storing and restoring all the states seems so complicated, in such cases like the test label is already using in the cluster.

What value do I pass in job submission if I only want a subset of nodes with a label, which I will do with evaluator requests? Exposing node label to job submission is not consistent with the current design.

If you think so, I will discard that part.

@craig1583 We didn't expose resource specs in the job submission API. The specs of requested resources are encoded in the Driver logic. Let's make the API consistent by removing node label from the job submission API.

> Interestingly, two other jobs both fail in Travis, one with finbugs and one with some system error.

Fair enough. I was just thinking that maybe the instructions can be coded in such a way that they don't need the version string anymore. If that doesn't work, we should add the file to the python script.

If we want to guarantee that REEF keeps running on Oracle Java 7, then it's better to try and keep `oraclejdk7` of course. Also, it will give us more statistics on transient test failures on Java side (which are fewer than on .NET side but still not non-existent).

@markusweimer Hmm... I ran the python script.  I'm not sure why `build.DotNet.props` still reference version 0.16. I will manually fix the files `build.DotNet.props` and `ReefOnSpark.scala` in this PR. How about registering a JIRA issue that fixes the python script?

I implmeneted in this way to avoid modify the original code. I just worried I can insert err code into original code and compatibility issues. I think refactoring the original code can be eliminate many duplicated code since It does not have much difference. What Do you think would be better?

Hi @shouhengyi-microsoft. Parquet.Net reads parquet files natively from disk or seekable stream and doesn't have any external dependencies. We also support .NET Standard 1.4/1.6 and .NET 4.5.1, both Windows and Linux or .NET Core. As an output it gives you a `DataSet` structure very similar to Apache Spark's DataSet, in fact we've tried to replicate it to ease adoption. It supports paging through the file in case it doesn't fit in memory as well. We have examples on the front page in GitHub how to use it, can I help you to integrate it into reef? Please contact me for any questions.
@tcNickolas are you OK with me merging it? We are seasonly low on committers right now (everyone is out on vacation :) )

@johnyangk Thanks for sharing!
I have a question about CLIMiniCluster. The description in your link saying `Using the CLI MiniCluster, users can simply start and stop a single-node Hadoop cluster`. But I think we need more than two slave nodes to test node labeling. Is it available to use multiple nodes with CLIMiniCluster?

I added a yarn node labeling example on `reef-examples`. You can see details [here](https://github.com/scan3/reef-example-nodelabel).

you can run this example with the command below.
```
yarn jar lang/java/reef-examples/target/reef-examples-0.16.0-SNAPSHOT-shaded.jar org.apache.reef.examples.yarnnodelabel.REEFYarnNodeLabelTest
```
